item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

West7man:

Your own libs for your own apps tend to work faster.

Oh ok :rolleyes:, you should probably write your own compiler as well, maybe design your own CPU, your own compiler and CPU for your own apps tend to work faster…

Ridiculous.

item.title: Transmitting Data in a Client-Server Model

item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Your Client-Server Model looks suspiciously like the Netty channel, encoder, decoder system.

Read full topic
item.source: Transmitting Data in a Client-Server Model

item.title: Transmitting Data in a Client-Server Model
item.dc:creator: @West7man West7man
item.description:
@West7man wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:20, topic:394205”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=491391.msg3594516#msg3594516 date=1304947683]
Do yourself a favour and just use Netty.
[/quote]

I’ve considered it. Although I think I can learn more by creating something myself, rather than using someone else’s code.[/quote]

Well, I have also used netty and MINA but actually I preffer to write the networking lib myself sometimes. Your own libs for your own apps tend to work faster.
I have done a similar framework. I didnt have decoding/encoding interfaces, these things were done on the fly while accepting data and sending data. It looked like sendPacket(Client client, Packet packet) and then this method took the data from the packet, put it into the stream and sent to the client/server. I accepted data byte by byte and when the packet was finished(and after that validated) it was sent for executing(had also PacketHandler interface). Ofcourse this kind of framework is very simple and might not be very good. I suggest to gain information about NIO designs, concepts etc.

Read full topic
item.source: Transmitting Data in a Client-Server Model

item.title: Transmitting Data in a Client-Server Model
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“T4_, post:27, topic:394205”][quote author=pkedpker link=topic=491391.msg3602983#msg3602983 date=1305782485]
yah why don’t you just do it, obviously you don’t have any problems atm… just want to let people know… from my view it looked like a runescape private server. You don’t gotta go to universities to make runescape servers. I can tell you right now it will not make you any money… I used to make private servers after only getting around 5$ in donations… over running some server for like 2 months. I quickly realized I can make more money collecting bottles in the street.

Not trying to ruin your dreams of making the best socket library we all had that dream but it’s been done, just trying to save you some time, get over it, save your time and save your life.
Good luck on your project.
[/quote]
OP’s thread isn’t a direct RSPS question.[/quote]

It doesn’t really have anything to do with RSPS. Granted, If I build a clean, functioning framework for networking, I would probably implement it into my RSPS, along with my IRC, HTTP, and FTP servers aswell.

Read full topic

You don’t gotta go to universities to make runescape servers. I can tell you right now it will not make you any money… I used to make private servers after only getting around 5$ in donations… over running some server for like 2 months. I quickly realized I can make more money collecting bottles in the street.

item.title: Transmitting Data in a Client-Server Model
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:22, topic:394205”]Except you’re completely neglecting 90% of the netty API. You’re not even doing it yourself – you’ve taken the approach that a handful of private servers use, and tried to turn it into a full feature-rich API.[/quote]Not really a reason to not learn the NIO API; doesn’t mean you cant look at Netty afterwards

Read full topic

http://code.google.com/p/kryonet/

Seems quite interesting, haven’t tried it myself but it’s probably the best solution if you have little to no netcode knowledge.

item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Except you’re completely neglecting 90% of the netty API. You’re not even doing it yourself – you’ve taken the approach that a handful of private servers use, and tried to turn it into a full feature-rich API.
